video.title: Create a C# Application from Start to Finish - Complete Course
video.description:
In this comprehensive 24-hour-long course, you will learn to use C# to build a complete application from start to finish.  Using .net and Visual Studio, we will construct a tournament tracker application that is fit to launch. The application uses Winforms, a class library, events, SQL database, text file data storage (in CSV format), custom events and more. 

⌨️ (00:00:00) 01 - Initial Planning
⌨️ (00:16:45) 02 - Overview Planning
⌨️ (00:46:09) 03 - Data Design
⌨️ (01:15:06) 04 - User Interface Design
⌨️ (01:34:26) 05 - Logic Planning
⌨️ (01:50:02) 06 - Class Library Creation
⌨️ (02:06:10) 07 - Form Building
⌨️ (03:08:24) 08 - SQL Database Design
⌨️ (04:12:49) 09 - Prize Form Wire Up
⌨️ (05:36:04) 10 - SQL Connection
⌨️ (06:46:37) 11 - Text Connection
⌨️ (07:44:24) 12 - Create Team Form Part 1
⌨️ (08:29:18) 13 - Create Team Form Part 2
⌨️ (09:12:34) 14 - Create Team Form Part 3
⌨️ (10:01:06) 15 - Create Tournament Form Part 1
⌨️ (10:33:21) 16 - Create Tournament Form Part 2
⌨️ (11:15:17) 17 - Create Tournament Form Part 3
⌨️ (12:34:12) 18 - Create Tournament Form Part 4
⌨️ (13:45:48) 19 - Create Tournament Form Part 5
⌨️ (16:12:12) 20 - Debugging
⌨️ (17:09:09) 21 - Dashboard Form
⌨️ (17:58:42) 22 - Tournament Viewer Part 1
⌨️ (19:07:33) 23 - Tournament Viewer Part 2
⌨️ (20:23:30) 24 - Refactoring
⌨️ (21:30:51) 25 - Error Handling
⌨️ (21:52:55) 26 - Emailing Users
⌨️ (23:01:27) 27 - Wrapping Up

🎥Tutorial from Tim Corey. Check out his channel: https://youtube.com/IAmTimCorey

🔗Tim's website: https://www.IAmTimCorey.com

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

And subscribe for new videos on technology: https://youtube.com/subscription_center?add_user=freecodecamp

topLevelComment.author: FoxHoundUnit89
topLevelComment.text:
4:58:00 if anyone else gets to this point and is confused because the reference isn't working, you might have done what I did and created the wrong kind of class library.  The program is not at all clear about this but you have to make sure you pick the right version of a class library, even though they all have identical names.  

You must ensure you pick the one that also allows you to target the exact same version of .NET FRAMEWORK that your TrackerUI solution is using.  

If you've already gotten this far it's okay. Just copy all of your scripts into a backup folder for TrackerLibrary, delete the old one, add a new one using the correct version of class library, copy your script backups into the new folder, and then in VS right click the new TrackerLibrary and add existing items.  Select all of your now restored scripts in the new folder and everything is fine.  Redo the reference as instructed in the video and if you did it right it'll work this time.

topLevelComment.author: Michael Bird
topLevelComment.text:
Amazing free course. 
Ran into issue at 6:32:32 -> First time inserting data into the db
Program would freeze at:
SqlConnectors.cs -> line: 'connection.Execture("dbo.spPrizes_Insert...);

Exception = System.Data.SqlClient.SqlException

(not sure if all of this required but the issue is now solved)
TrackerLibrary -> References -> Manage NuGet Packages -> 
1. System.Configuration.ConfigurationManager
2. System.Data.SqlClient
----(issue still persisting)---
Sql Server Configuration Manager -> Properties (state = running) -> Log On -> 'Built-in account:' = Local System -> Apply

Sql Server Configuration Manager -> Properties (state = running) -> Service
Write down 'Host Name' = DESKTOP-xxxxxxx

Edit -> App.config
<add name="Tournaments" connectionString="Server=DESKTOP-XXXXXX; Database=Tournaments;Trusted_Connection=True;" providerName="System.Data.SqlClient"/>
 
Saved
Now working

topLevelComment.author: Sr Viejo
topLevelComment.text: TIP OF THE DAY:  When comparing against a constant, list the constant first, not last.  That way, if you mistype the comparison (ie. == or !=), the compiler will throw an error and you won't have to spend time debugging, only to find an assignment where comparison was intended.  For example, use "if ( true == variableName )" instead of "if ( variableName == true )" so that if you accidentally entered a single equal sign (ie. "if ( true = variableName )"), the compiler will throw an error.

Hi Tim,

Had a quick skim of the first few lessons, 

Looks interesting and good to see that there is more of a planned approach to it, rather than lets build a form or print "Hello World".

Do you have something more commercially based?
As in reality, the first thing that would be developed (for an company/commercial/industrial application, which people would be working on if they get a job as a programmer), would be the logging screen the User (Developer, admin, manager and user/analyst) logins and the client/end user logins, the data structure for this information, access rights/permissions to sections/operations/views of the applications and logging/audit information regarding it's uses and users actions.

While not sexy, I think a good example is a helpdesk/ticket logging system, which you can include Desktop, Web and Mobile Application development, which you could added asset management to, for a stock tracking and control elements to it. 
(as well as a whole range of other functionality/application/processing/interfacing) 

I'll try to find some time to look through the course, though not looking to develop a tournament planner.

Regards,

Keith.

replies.author: Raimundas Mac
replies.text:
You need to make both projects .net 4.8 framework. If one is .net 4.8 and the other one is .net core it will not work, because .net core runtime is deprecated and does not combine with .net 4.8.

Easiest way to do it is to create another same type of project under the same solution that would use the same .net and then copy paste all written code to that new project. Then you will be able to reference it.

topLevelComment.author: Alfarabi Bolatbek
topLevelComment.text:
Whoever who don't know how rounds, matchup system works. here is my explanation. 
Let's imagine there are 7 teams participating in tournament, but there have to be 4 match consisting of 8 teams in the first round, so we have to add one "bye" team.  When creating first round, Tim wants real teams participate with "bye" teams like teamOne<->bye, teamTwo<->bye and e.t.c. In our case only teamOne<->bye and others will compete with each other. Firstly we add teamOne to the first matchupEntryModel and we have to get rid of one "bye". Because of that, we will just assign new MatchupModel meaning that only teamOne alone is in matchupModel("bye" counter = 0). Then we proceed to teamTwo<->teamThree and so on.
Hope it will be helpful. 

p.s sorry for my bad english

replies.author: jakenastysnake
replies.text: @LIEFHEBBER I can definitely tell I’ve gotten much better over the past couple of months. The biggest thing that has helped me to manage bigger projects is breaking the code down into different classes, for example I could have a “Comboboxes” class to handle drawing custom comboboxes, or a “DataGrids” class to handle populating data.  To me it’s easier to manage than having everything in one form/class. Also, I like to use public static methods in classes because it makes it simple to call that method from another form/class, but some say it’s bad practice, but it definitely works for me!

topLevelComment.author: dralekoz
topLevelComment.text:
Hello and thanks for the tutorial.
I am having an issue in https://youtu.be/wfWxdh-_k_4?list=PLqoL7gAFq7Y5EqwG26o9OBesZVmw8rpTo&t=17854.
When adding the  reference of TrackerLibrary to TrackerUI it was not getting "recognized" because:
Project....\TrackerLibrary.csproj targets "netcoreapp3.1".It cannot be referenced by a project that targets ".NETFramework,Version=v4.7.2"

-TrackerLibrary  has TargetFramework --> .NET Core 3.1  ,  Output Type--> Class Library  
-TrackerUI           has TargetFramework --> .NETFramework 4.7.2  ,  Output Type--> Windows Form Application  

I cannot recall why there are different Frameworks but is there a way to change them and which framework should be used by both of them? 
Is there someone who has an idea on how to fix that.

Edit & Solution: I have created another Class Library and now made sure that it is the target Framework is a .NET Framework 4.7.2 :
Then I just copied all the classes I have created to the new Library and renamed the namespaces.

replies.author: Чале
Iwky
Чале
replies.text: I am not sure that i understand your question, or at least the aim of the question, but from my very poor knowledge about the subject, I will tell you that you need to initialize the list before adding any object in it. If you don't do that, infamous "Object Reference Not Set to an Instance of an Object" will emerge sooner or later. You can initialize it in a constructor  or directly on a field. From my perspective, the field is the better option, since that way you will not forget to do it for sure.

Hi Tim.

Before all, THANKS A LOT for offering this opportunity to learn, I have spent two weeks following your course.

After assisting lesson 22 and 23  and following your wonderful course, I have the following issue with the LoadMatchups method in the TournamentViewerForm.

When the program starts and the tournament is selected, the sequence in LoadMatchups seems to be OK:
- In a given moment enters the foreach loop, validates the matchup round.
- Within the if, the selected matchup list is cleared (selectedMatchups.Clear())
- Jumps to the following line of code (the next foreach)

When I change the round in the roundDrop element, it correctly triggers the roundDropDown_SelectedIndexChanged event and calls the LoadMatchups method. But the sequence changes:

- In a given moment enters the foreach loop, validates the matchup round.
- Within the if, the selected matchup list is cleared (selectedMatchups.Clear())

- CHANGED BEHAVIOR: before going to the next line, it "triggers" the matchupListBox_SelectedIndexChanged event, so calling the LoadMatchup method with a null parameter. of course this creates an EXCEPTION.

- Jumps to the following line of code (the next foreach)

Extra information:
- Same happens when the checkbox "unplayedOnlyChecbox" is used and the event unplayedOnlyCheckbox_CheckedChanged is triggered
- I am using VS 2019
- .NETFramework,Version=v4.7.2
- Based on the framework version, I guess I am using C# version 7.3

I checked your code in GitHub and in principle everything matches, can you please provide some light?

topLevelComment.author: Chocolate Man
topLevelComment.text:
Mine didn't work around 06:32:00. It was due to the configuration in app.config at 05:55:00.
The error: 
System.Data.SqlClient.SqlException: 'A network-related or instance-specific error occurred while establishing a connection to SQL Server. The server was not found or was not accessible. Verify that the instance name is correct and that SQL Server is configured to allow remote connections. (provider: SQL Network Interfaces, error: 26 - Error Locating Server/Instance Specified)'
The solution: open App.config and change connection string to this: connectionString="Server=localhost;Database=Tournaments;Trusted_Connection=True;"
If that doesn't work then open SQL Server Management Studio, copy the value of Server name and replace localhost with your server name.

topLevelComment.author: Grant Samson
topLevelComment.text:
When doing the bindings for the lists in the tournamentViewer form, I kept running into an issue where the list load functions would break, because the selected item was null. After stepping through the code it seemed that the issue was when refreshing the lists by setting the datasource = null, that was triggering the selected_index_changed function (which reran the respective load function) but passing null as the selectedItem. Adding a null check before the load seemed to alleviate this issue, and I didn't run into the problem you had with the 2nd round not refreshing the "not yet determined" value in the matchup list, nor did I need to use BindingLists.
What confuses me is that you didn't seem to encounter the selected_index_changed function call when nulling your data sources for the lists. Is this a version issue with Visual Studio?

topLevelComment.author: Chandler Bing
topLevelComment.text: Nice tutorial! I've got one question, though. Here at 10:35:59 you created an instance of CreatePrizeForm by using new directly. What happens if this line is invoked several time? Will there be more and more CreatePriceForm instances in the memory? I used to do similar things with Java Swing, and each time I create a window like this it takes abt 10MB more memory, without being released by GC when it's closed.

replies.author: IAmTimCorey
replies.text: Yes, it creates a new instance each time, although the memory usage is nowhere near that much. Typically the user would only create one at a time but I have had people that like to create multiple at one time so they open an instance for each. With .NET, once you close a form and don't hold a reference to it, that memory can be reclaimed by the garbage collector. It does not immediately reclaim it because it is actually too expensive to do so. Instead, it reclaims the memory as it needs new memory in an efficient pattern.

topLevelComment.author: Thomas Hohner
topLevelComment.text: As a MCSE, somone who works in SQL Server 8-10 hours daily for the last 7 years. DO NOT NAME your PK id. Freaking nightmare to write SQL against tables like that

replies.author: Thomas Hohner
replies.text: @IAmTimCorey  a second note, just because  a large company does something or practices a design pattern does not make it correct.. Example i have heard a very large multi-billion dollar company uses email addies for the PK on their user table.

replies.author: Thomas Hohner
replies.text:
I want to start by saying your vids are great, no disrespect intended. 
I would also say I have never seen this as a recommended field name by Microsoft, maybe it’s the default by EF, but in MS T-SQl world not recommended anywhere I can find in my SQl experience, or any of the 7 MS SQL exams I took, including forums like SQL Server Central which is all about T-SQL. I have this same argument with other developers that only see it from their side of the fence. However, there is also agreement from many other devs who have to write any kind of extensive SQL queries.  I would hope you may agree that using generic keywords such as Date, Name, Description . etc. would be a bad practice in table design. I would also ask what’s wrong with fully qualifying a field name and is there any benefit for just calling it Id vs a name that would match an FK in another table without aliasing?  
My main point is if as a dev when you design tables and you don’t want BI, DBA’s or anyone else to hate you with a passion. Use a fully qualified name.
Again, your vids are top notch, learning a lot just a minor disagreement on table design.

replies.author: IAmTimCorey
replies.text: Why (since this is the recommended field name by Microsoft (EF) as well as most of the rest of the industry)? If it is because you don't know which table it comes from, that is never an issue. If you have more than one table in a query, you always have to specify the table name. If you want more than one ID in a query, you have to alias it. I get that but that's not a big deal. If you have a problem with joins not being to the same name, that shouldn't be an issue since Id always refers to the PK where PersonId refers to the FK. I've been working with databases with Id for the PK for over two decades in dozens of companies (from small to Fortune 500) and never had an issue.

replies.author: meandmyself1600
replies.text:
I've got 15 years experience in SQL and Scripting/Programming in general, 4 of these years in C#. So far I never created a complete application but was always just writing extensions for Windows Workflows. Now I had the feeling it is time to move on and get a bit into software development.
Really like this tutorial so far (currently halfway through). The author is going through all steps of the development process instead of jumping right into coding. He also explains what he is doing and adds bugs/mistakes here and there. That last point is what I like the most. You can clearly see, that this series of videos wasn't shot until it was picture perfect. Instead you can learn a bit about refactoring your code (because you realize your first idea wasn't perfect) or tracking bugs with some real examples. 



5/5 for the first 15 chapters and think i will stick to this rating.

replies.author: meandmyself1600
replies.text: @Nathan Sodja I did some refactoring. Basic idea: Create a backup of your solution (just in case). Rename your "TrackerLibrary" to "TrackerLibraryOld". Add a new project "TrackerLibrary" and recreate the folders (DataAccess and Models iirc). In this new project/these folders, you use "add existing item" and pick the classes needed from your filesystem, folder "TrackerLibraryOld". They will now be duplicated from "...Old" to the freshly created project. Since your new project has the same name, as the old one, all namespaces should be fine.

replies.author: meandmyself1600
replies.text: You probably created the wrong type of project. Had that happening too and realized, that VS2019 offers e.g. three class libraries (.Net Standard, .Net Framework, .Net Core). I ended up in creating a new project for my TrackerLibrary (.Net Framework was working for me) and added my classes via "Add existing item"

replies.author: bloxcraft
replies.text:
It would be beneficial to learn the basics which Tim does go through and explain however, he only breaks down 1 Stored Procedure's SQL Script and then another Test dummy one for further explanation.  The remaining Stored Procedure Scripts are not shown in the video and thus some people's outbursts and demands.

That being said.  Tim does show you the Full Relationship Diagram as well as providing very descriptive names for said Stored Procedures.  It doesn't take a genius to figure out that they are all based off of the exact same 1st SQL Script example with a few changes here and there with regards to Inner joins ( All of which is very descriptive in the names as to which parameter names to set and parse as well as the actual field names in each table and their data types to be used).

If this still confuses you, then I would recommend doing a beginners course to get you comfortable, confident and competent enough to be able to move through the material.  It is beneficial to be able to resolve problems on our own as it's inevitable that you will need to do so throughout your programing career.

Hope this helps (^^.)

topLevelComment.author: Jacob Nyhart
topLevelComment.text: 3:38:45 For the record, the limit on the number of characters is "technically" 320 (64 before the @ symbol+ the @ symbol + 255 characters after the @ symbol. The RFC (2821) that governs the MAIL and RCPT commands in an email server limit it to 254 characters - so for practical purposes anything longer than 254 characters wouldn't work in just about every mail server around the globe - so setting it to nvarchar(254) is reasonable.

topLevelComment.author: ctbram0627
topLevelComment.text: All these examples suffer from the same problem.  Anyone with a small amount of study can write a monolithic single thread application.  I found very quickly when I started writing REAL applications that 90 percent of the time I need to have a gui front end talking to one to n multiple threads communicating with other things.  Nobody seems to want to deal with demonstrating the proper way to use Thread, Tasks, Callbacks, event-handlers or the other half dozen ways C# has had incorporated into the language over the years to handle proper multi-threaded applications.  So that now there are humpteen different ways to handle the same problem of handling threads and events making the task even more confusing to the uninitiated. This is what there needs to be training on.  When to use threads, tasks, callbacks, event and how to implement them in real world applications!

replies.author: IAmTimCorey
replies.text: Check out the other videos on my channel ( https://www.youtube.com/user/IAmTimCorey ). I cover Async/Await (and advanced cases), Delegates, Events, and more. While there are a lot of good uses for Async, there weren't any in this particular application. The key to remember is that just making something async doesn't help you. In fact, it can make your application more unstable and slower. You need to be CPU-bound or network-bound before it is useful to use async. In a current series I'm doing on my channel (TimCo Retail Manager), I show how to work with a WebAPI (using WPF as the front-end right now, although we are going to add ASP.NET MVC and possibly a mobile app too). That will get into async somewhat, since calls will be network-bound.

replies.author: IAmTimCorey
replies.text:
I hear what you are saying and I'm sorry you are disappointed. The focus of the course was on C#. I committed to doing all of the coding on screen. I wanted to do all of the SQL on screen as well but I quickly realized that to do so would have taken another 5-10 hours. That would have put this course well beyond the size I wanted it to be (it was already long). Add to that the issue of people coming to watch a C# video and ending up watching the first 15 hours before they ever really saw C#. That's not ideal. On the other hand, while SQL is a fairly necessary skill when it comes to working with C# if you are using data, I didn't want to assume everyone knew SQL. I had already designed every table on paper (and on video). I decided the best thing to do would be to show you how to create a table (which you could then follow the same pattern for the other tables), how to create a stored procedure (which you could then follow for the other stored procedures - you know what each is called, what inputs it has and what the output is so you have all of the relevant information to do it on your own), and then how to create a relationship (which isn't strictly necessary but since I showed off the relationships, I wanted to show you how to set one up). To top it all off, this entire application can work just fine without SQL at all. That also means you can skip some of the coding and cut down on the amount of time it takes to finish this course. Since the focus of this course is to teach you how to write C# code and not SQL scripts, I figured teaching you how to anyway but letting you then finish the work was a good compromise.


I get that you want to see EVERYTHING on the screen, including all of SQL. I have debated going back and creating those extra 5-10 hours (maybe compressing them a bit). I try to listen to my viewers as much as possible. How I weigh things is based upon the number and type of requests. I'll add your vote to the list.

topLevelComment.author: simply Incorrigible
topLevelComment.text:
10 hours into the vid as a code along.  
If you don't know SQL, you will have to learn.  
This isn't a beginner/new to programming course at all.  
You should be familiar with data types, classes, enums, interfaces, debugging, win forms, using, namespace, event handlers, intimate knowledge of visual studio 2017 &  sql{install, create servers, database, tables, queries, write stored procedures, m$ sql management studio}.

all that is in the first 10 hours.

replies.text: I create all of the source code on screen. I also show you how to create the tables and stored procedures and I design them on screen. I do offer this as a paid course as well, with full source code, database scripts, a bonus video on sending text messages from your app, and a 40+ page design guide if you really want those scripts. I also offer add-on courses for this course that replace the UI with WPF and ASP.NET MVC.
